intro: Angadenia sylvestris, commonly known as the forest angadenia, is a flowering plant native to the southeastern United States. It belongs to the family Apiaceae, which includes carrots and parsley, and is characterized by its compound leaves and small, clustered flowers. The plant typically grows in moist, wooded areas and thrives in partial to full shade. Its botanical features include a slender stem, finely divided leaves, and white to pale yellow flowers that bloom in the spring. Angadenia sylvestris is often found in wetlands and is considered a rare and endangered species in some regions.
